6305308659|4.0|David Wagner (Tobey Maguire) is an high school kid obsessed with the 50's TV series \\"Pleasantville\\", which seems an ideal place, far from his girlless, nerdlike life with feuding divorced parents.  He is mysteriously transported, with his sister Jennifer (Reece Witherspoon) into the black and white world of Pleasantville.  At first David eagerly adopts the mode of life there, but he and Jennifer soon bring change--and color--to Pleasantville--both good and bad changes.<br />  Well cast, with William H. Macy doing wonders as the kids' \\"father\\" in Pleasantville, Joan Allen as their \\"mother\\", and Jeff Daniels as the owner of the malt shop who, as things change in Pleasantville, develops a long-suppressed interest in Allen.  Jane Kaczmarek does a nice small part as the kids' real mother, one quite different from \\"Malcolm\\".<br />  In some ways nicely thought out (\\"Bud\\" is gone an hour, the time of two weekly episodes in Pleasantville (and it is pretty clear what the episodes would have been about, until the kids change things)) but it seems like two weeks in Pleasantville, in others not so well thought out (How could Bud and Bill paint a mural in the dark?  If the Pleasantville basketball team is undefeated, and there is no other school, who do they play?).  Still, quite thought provoking.<br />  Well shot, with scenes in a bowling alley evoking \\"Patton\\" and at Lovers Lane evoking \\"The Shawshank Redemption\\".<br />  I withhold a fifth star due to the heavyhandedness of the messages that Gary Ross gives us in the second half of the movie.  It could have been done better, more subtly.  Also, Maguire's acting isn't directed quite as well as it could be by Ross.  Maguire is made to come out with these profound statements (\\"Maybe it isn't just the sex\\" \\"There is no right house.  There is no right car\\") in the same offhand, almost squeaky manner.  It becomes a bit tiresome.<br />  The DVD features are quite good, including the trailer, audio commentary, and being able to watch the movie with just the music, by Randy Newman and very nice.<br />  Recommended.the movie with just the music, by Randy Newman and very nice.<br />  Recommended.
B0000DD7LB|5.0|I agree that this album is going to get a lot of bad publicity for the simple fact that it is Britney Spears. However, the album is a production masterpiece, it's immaculate. All the sounds and vocals are so clean and solid, it would be hard to criticize the quality of sound that this album has. Britney definitely compensate for what she lacks in vocals with musical creativity. At least now, no one can critize Britney of conforming to pressures to be a role model; she's grown a lot and seem to experimenting with verying musical types. This album is far more mature and a lot more progressive than her other releases, and more than half the album is very electronic, almost techno sounding. It's an interesting album with many differenct styles, and it is definitely worth purchasing-- maybe the future direction of Pop/Rock music??.

B0000C7PRY|3.0|This is my third revision of my review here. When I originally purchased this album, I had my preconcieved notions.  One of the major contributing factors to my being a fan of SB for so long was Neal's ability to write progressive music (and lyrics) which were accessable.  Most music which is labeled as \\"progressive\\" tends to be pompous or intellectual (or both).  While with SB, Neal wrote music which was accessable to a wide audiance, yet was still considered progressive.    I don't think anyone who has listened to the album could argue that the music is not excellent.  Neal proves himself as both a Keyboard player and a fairly accomplished guitarist.  And when you put his talent together with Mike Portnoy, watch out!  However, I couldn't put my finger on what I didn't like about this album.  At first, I thought it was simply what most people were saying...that the album suffered because Neal is now writing progressive music under the CCM guise.  After listening to the album a couple dozen times, I don't entirely believe this is true.  The thing that's bothering me is that I believe progressive artists are supposed to challenge themselves to break new ground.  Lyrically, this album does not.  Furthermore, I believe if Neal continues in this direction (which it looks like both of his newest post-Testimony projects are shaping up this way) then the CCM world may be finding itself with a new great talent while the progressive world may soon be losing one.    That having been said, the reason I'm giving this album as high a rating as I am is because this is one of most heartfelt and touching albums to which I have ever listened.  Progressive -- CCM -- whatever you want to call it, you can feel the pure emotion pouring into the microphone when he sings \\"I Am Willing\\" and \\"Somber Days.\\" Testimony simply is a truly touching story of one man's struggle to find himself.  Coupled with the fact that this is the creative genius behind SB (teaming up with, arguably) the most talented drummer on the face of the earth (save for Neal Peart, anyway) this album is definitely worth the price tag.

U.\\" does, it is hard not to love the character, as brought to full-color life by Richardson.  <br />  The only extra given on the DVDs, other than cast biographies, is a short BBC segment discussing the controversy over \\"To Play The King\\", or, to be more specific, over a line which some felt implied that the King used to send out for prostitutes (in context, it clearly does not, it implied he sent out for well-born ladies who would feel it their duty to come).<br />  Each DVD contains four 50 minute episodes, so it is a good buy.<br />Recommended.
B0000DJZA5|5.0|Since 1970, we all had to deal with a &quot;non-sense&quot; version of Let It Be -- the version Phil Spector basically &quot;overproduced&quot;.  Yes, it sounded nice and beautiful but what it actually was, was like taking a great hamburger and then seasoning it with honey. <BR>Now finally, we get the real hamburger and how it sould really taste.<br />The Beatles have given us great music and yes, their marketing efforts have laways been top-notch - look at Beatles 1, but this is an album of songs they way the Beatles really sounded.  Now if you don't care about that, fine, but for people who want realism of how four guys made incredible music, this CD cannot be missed.  If you like your dinner sugar-coated, then I'm sorry, you may want to be a Phil Spector fan.  The Beatles were three guitars and drums and that's it...unless you add Billy Preston for two songs.  George Martin did his magic on experimentation along with the boys and that's how masterpieces came about.  Applaud Paul and Ringo for this CD...as well as George who apparently gave his blessing before he left us.  Thanks to Yoko as well.
B0000BWVCM|4.0|While I was more than a little disappointed in both the writing and production values of the first \\"X-Men\\" movie, the sequel more than makes up for the deficiencies of the original.<br />\\"X-Men United\\" lives up to its name: Whereas the original X-Men movie was basically \\"Wolverine, guest-starring some X-Men,\\" the sequel greatly expands the time we spend with the other characters, and all of them are the better for it, including a more compelling vision of Pyro than even the best of the comics has shown us.<br />While the story picks up months after the original, this time, the story is bigger, grander, and more exciting. The film hits the ground running with an amazing sequence introducing the teleporting Nightcrawler, in an eye-popping attack on the Oval Office. Contrast this to the obviously foam rubber girders wrapped around the X-Men at the climax of the last film, and it's immediately obvious that the special effects this time around will be something to enjoy, not something to overlook, and so they are.<br />As always, the acting, particularly by Hugh Jackman and Ian McKellan, is top-notch. B0000DJZA5|5.0|Let it Be stands up as a great album in this newly released 'as they intended' version, for anyone who might have been concerned about it somehow losing some luster.  Of course, for many Beatles fans it didn't have much 'luster' to begin with.  The title, \\"Let It Be...Naked\\", is quite appropros, as many of the songs are absolutely laid bare here.<br />     First off, most of the 11 songs sound much like they did on the original, in terms of the underlying takes used by Phil Spector to build the monstrosity he eventually produced.  A couple seem to be alternate takes, but, after only a couple of runs through, I'm not yet positive.  One thing I will mention, before I get to the songs, is that I'm not entirely positive about the mix they arrived at...the vocals are far forward and some of the instruments (most noticeable in the little guitar riffs throughout the songs) get a little buried.  The bass is a little on the muddy side as well.  Don't get me wrong, it sounds great...much better than the original...and it actually sounds much better on headphones than in the car (perhaps I need to adjust the equalization in the car).<br />     The lineup is also different, starting with \\"Get Back\\", which sounds much the same, though a little plainer.  On this song, there seems to be something, well, missing.  I'll have to listen to it back-to-back with the 'original'.  The vocal is surprising, being a little more front and center it really shows how interesting a singer Paul could be (he's always PAUL, but he has always tried a little different elements here and there...accents, etc.).  \\"Dig a Pony\\" is next and this one is much like \\"Get Back\\".  I think the original versions of both had more 'background noise' going on, to give them that 'live' feel.  That is absent here, so they sound a little sparse on occasion.  This song holds up better, mainly because there is so much more going on (two separate guitars playing riffs all the way through PLUS the keyboard).  The originalsof these two had no orchestration added, so, again, not TOO different...<br />     \\"For You Blue\\", one of my personal favorites, is VERY different.  On headphones it sounds like 'the boys' are having a jam right there in my head...on speakers it sounds like you are in an intimate room with them and they're just playing a great blues jam.  The song always sounded like a jam, but now it is much, much cleaner...another one to which Spector had artificial background added, I think.  This version is just, well, it's just plain great.  As you'll see later, Harrison seems to have made out the best on this disc.<br />    Now we're getting to the songs that really had a lot of 'work' done to them by Spector.  \\"The Long and Winding Road\\" sounds VERY different.  If you recall, it was always a nice ballad, though somewhat weighed down by the comprehensive orchestration layered on top of it.  Now it sounds like a you are in the smoky lounge of some fantastic club back in the days when such places were 'it'.  The piano work is amazing, and the band is merely there for emphasis on occasion...the whole thing is almost 'cocktail jazz'.  This is the way Billy Joel always heard this song when he listened to it, I bet, because he ripped it off big time.  Oh, and again, Paul shows his range as a vocalist.<br />     \\"Two of Us\\" just sounds great.  On this one, Paul and John's voices ARE the centerpiece, so the mix is quite appropriate.  The song sounds so, well, CLEAN.  It really could be the Everly Brothers.  They are both SO good, and the production shows them off well...the two guitars are separated to each channel but kept back enough that the voices are never overrun.  The bass is in the center, as are the drums (with that great muffled thump that sounds like either a train on the old segmented tracks or a pair of trotting horses), the bass (or is it a low-tuned guitar?) providing the melodic counterpoint.  It's just a great song...these guys could arrange a song better than anybodyever has, or probably ever will (they just constructed their songs so, so, 'right').<br />    \\"I've Got a Feeling\\" is very stripped down compared to the 'original'.  This one actually might be a different take than that one, as the vocals sound quite different in places...especially the backing vocals.  But in other spots there are things that sound EXACTLY the same...could anybody have played that single bent note punctuating the bridge exactly the same way more than once?  Maybe they just moved the backing vocals up in the mix.  Oh, and they definitely lost the extraneous noise that Spector somehow felt substitued for layered instruments to build his \\"wall of sound\\".<br />    \\"One After 909\\" was always a great blues-rock jam, and it's lost nothing here.  It was pretty raw originally, and is so here.  But it's even more fun as they've managed to pull some of the ad libbed comments up from the background...and, again, it's a bit cleaner.  The solo guitar work really screams out at you...in fact, I don't remember the main solo being so long, and I don't remember Billy Preston doing extemporaneous keyboard work during it, but both those elements are here.  Just some good rock and roll...<br />    \\"Don't Let Me Down\\" is another one that is much cleaner and far more crisp.  Again, it's hard to enumerate exactly what is different, but it pops much more.  One thing is that Billy Preston's keyboard has become a centerpiece of the song...it ranges throughout the entire length and is more emphasized in the mix.  The bridge is really emphasized in this mix, and sounds very different....Lennon screams \\"It's a love that lasts forever\\" in an amazing, plaintive wail that just reminds you that, with all his amazing talents, he could have been 'merely' a rock singer and he would STILL be a legend.  Preston also has a fabulous keyboard solo over the last 20 seconds that I have no memory of hearing, at least not so crystal clear...great work, too, so I am very glad they decided to enhance it in this mix.<br />    Ah, the other Harrison song...\\"I Me Mine\\".  This song shocked me.  I always loved this song, and wished I could hear it without the lavish orchestration that drowned it.  It's better than I ever imagined it.  George wrote the best stripped-down-4-piece songs of anyone in the band, and it shows here.  You WILL listen to this one over and over and over...listen to the 'big picture', then just the rythym acoustic guitar in the left channel, the counterpoint bass notes on the guitar in the right channel, the sparse organ riffs and chords sprinkled throughout, the low electric guitar buried way deep playing occasional riffs and exploding out for the chorus and, finally, Harrison's pure, soulfull voice bewailing the fall of the world's humanity (OK, he was mostly talking about his bandmates, but it works).  It is just an amazing, incredible song...listen to it on a really good set of headphones, as loud as you can handle it.<br />    \\"Across the Universe\\" is another song which benefits greatly from this new treatment (compared to Spector's mistreatment).  One would think that it would be TOO plain without the orchestration, but it is wonderful...there is sparse and subtle sitar work throughout that complements the melody perfectly.  This song remains the floaty dream that it was, but here it is far more interesting and rewarding.  Lennon's vocal is astounding in its warble-free journey through the upper registers.  His vocal style on this song is so different from some of his other signature songs, like \\"Twist and Shout\\", \\"Imagine\\", \\"Julia\\", etc., that it is hard to accept that it is him...it's almost childlike in its innocence.  <br />    Finally, \\"Let it Be\\".  Another clean and crisp recording.  The first verse is the same, for the most part, and when the chorus comes in during the first, well, chorus, it is far more subdued...it sounds like it's just 'the boys'.  The song still builds up as it goes verse by verse, but without the muddiness of the original (actually, each instrument receives its due here).  Ringo's work is front and center on this song, and it is pin perfect.  Paul's voice is brought forward in the mix and overrides all else, as it should because it is yet another stunning vocal performance from him (his vocal range always astounds me).  This song is one that, once it is over, makes you go \\"Yup, that's the way it should be.\\"<br />    One more thing I should mention and haven't yet is the drum work of Ringo.  The more I revisit my Beatles collection, the more I appreciate his talent.  Perhaps the ultimate compliment to a drummer is that you don't notice him, but I feel it's safe to say most other drummers WOULD be noticed in this band, and not in a good way.  His playing on this album is fantastic, perfectly matched to each song and interesting enough that you could listen to just the drum tracks on most of the songs and be quite satisfied.  I think he's an underrated drummer, perhaps because people forget to put him in the perspective of his time and are wowed by the later exploits of Bonham, Moon, etc.<br />    As with all 'single track' (live) recordings, there are a couple of rough edges.  These would have been removed with multi-tracking but they hadn't wanted to do that on this record originally.  As a result, there are a couple of half-sung words and a little bit of continuity issues with vocal styling...and it's great.  It's so intimate.  <br />    So, why is it that this is SO much better than the Spector-defiled version?  I think much of it has to do with all the little touches that the Beatles added within their songs...and how Spector somehow buried them in his mix of these songs.  It's hard to identify all the things he added to the songs, but all he did was create a \\"wall of mud\\" that buried, what turns out to be, great songs.  Actually, Beatles fans the world over have known they were great songs all along, it was just too frustrating (and a bit depressing) to think about what they could have been.  Now we know.
B000084T18|1.0|50 cent????<BR>If someone offered me 50 cents to buy this c.d. from me, I'd sell it and give the person change back too!!!!!!<BR>Where has all the originality gone?????
0679405372|5.0|I just finished Virginia Woolf's TO THE LIGHTHOUSE, and I am not sure what to write about it, except that it's a brilliant, fulfilling read, very rich and layered and nuanced and wonderful. It's a singular work that facilitates new understanding and insight, and makes the point effectively that the drama-rama of the human mind can supercede or at least equal the drama of the world around us.<br />The Ramsay family is the center of the story, and it is at their home in the Hebrides that the first section takes place, &quot;The Window.&quot; In fact, this section, which covers only part of a day in time, comprises 125 pages of the 209-page book. In a way similar to that of MRS. DALLOWAY, Woolf switches the perspective among the Ramsay family and some of their guests, Lily, an indepedent single woman, the Ramsay children, and Charles Tansley, a student of Mr. Ramsay, a philosopher.<br />There are threads of the issue of femininity in the book. What do the differing ways in which Mrs. Ramsay, mother of eight and supportive wife, and Lily, single woman, painter, enact their feminity mean? How do they deal with and understand and love each other? What forces do they unleash on each other?<br />The book deals skillfully with the perception of the passage of time, as &quot;The Window&quot; deals with that short bit, focusing, I found, the book's most amazing and engaging section on the dinner party that night. The second section, &quot;Time Passes,&quot; is merely 20 pages, but covers ten years, and the final section, &quot;The Lighthouse&quot; is one morning. There are all kinds of<br />reminders of the fluidity of time in the text, a skull of an animal on the wall in the children's nursery that causes them to be unable to sleep, as well as Mrs. Ramsay's glance back into the dining room at the end of the party and her realization that the success of the evening, which was somewhat hard won, is ephemeral and over, already in the past.<br />The second section has a different view of time, almost looking at the house from nature's point of view as time ravages the house through the war when the family isn't using it. It's very meditative. Major events in the lives of the people who attended the dinner are enclosed in brackets, as side notes, for the passage of time and the entropy that ensues is the major drama here. We see the lives and deaths of the characters as small things, part of a greater cycle that winds on and on in a more eternal, less fleeting, way.<br />What Woolf begins in the first section, she deals with more strongly in the third, I think, and that is that the validity of each person's differing perception of the others is equal. Two of the Ramsay children, James and Cam, go with their father and a fisherman and his boy to the lighthouse in the sailboat. James despises his father, while Cam sees his weaknesses and loves him for his vulnerabilities. She knows how James feels and feels drawn to protect James, too, but she knows a different father than James does.<br />I think that was what struck me the most about the book, the way the characters' combined perceptions assemble a greater truth and understanding than each of them singly has.<br />Woolf has a great insight and beautifully descriptive and engaging way of writing about thought as dramatic and intimate. Woolf writes about such things, the pleasure of picking up a pleasant and soothing thought so elegantly, that it doesn't seem to be writing on a page, but access to another's mind, and the part of the truth he or she holds.<br />And overall the writing is simply stunning.<br />In the first section, one of the characters loses a brooch on the beach, and they discuss going back to look for it the next day. By the time the book ends, the lost brooch seems so far away, in some deep and distant memory. I think this one detail is a mark of the beauty and success of the book.view of time, almost looking at the house from nature's point of view as time ravages the house through the war when the family isn't using it. It's very meditative. Major events in the lives of the people who attended the dinner are enclosed in brackets, as side notes, for the passage of time and the entropy that ensues is the major drama here. We see the lives and deaths of the characters as small things, part of a greater cycle that winds on and on in a more eternal, less fleeting, way. <br />What Woolf begins in the first section, she deals with more strongly in the third, I think, and that is that the validity of each person's differing perception of the others is equal. Two of the Ramsay children, James and Cam, go with their father and a fisherman and his boy to the lighthouse in the sailboat. James despises his father, while Cam sees his weaknesses and loves him for his vulnerabilities. She knows how James feels and feels drawn to protect James, too, but she knows a different father than James does. <br />I think that was what struck me the most about the book, the way the characters' combined perceptions assemble a greater truth and understanding than each of them singly has. <br />Woolf has a great insight and beautifully descriptive and engaging way of writing about thought as dramatic and intimate. Woolf writes about such things, the pleasure of picking up a pleasant and soothing thought so elegantly, that it doesn't seem to be writing on a page, but access to another's mind, and the part of the truth he or she holds.<br />And overall the writing is simply stunning. <br />In the first section, one of the characters loses a brooch on the beach, and they discuss going back to look for it the next day. By the time the book ends, the lost brooch seems so far away, in some deep and distant memory. I think this one detail is a mark of the beauty and success of the book.

B0000DJZA5|4.0|First, the title is stupid.  \\"Get Back\\"--the original title for the sessions that became \\"Let It Be\\"--would have been better and less goofy, or perhaps \\"The Get Back Sessions\\" except that would be misleading.<br />Second, everything here will be familiar; this is NOT a new recording and it is NOT hard to tell where Phil Spector grafted things onto the various songs.  Don't go in expecting a revelation along the lines of, \\"Ah, so this is what they recorded!\\"  If you've ever seen Paul McCartney in concert or listened to his live albums, especially Wings Over America, then you already have a pretty good idea of what \\"The Long and Winding Road\\" sounds like on this album.  If you have the Beatles' Past Masters Volume Two, then you've heard the recording of \\"Across the Universe\\" that is on here (except that they removed the bird sounds).  Actually, \\"Long and Winding Road\\" is the same recording used on the original Let It Be album--Spector just slowed it down and added a choir and orchestra.  \\"Across the Universe\\" is the same recording on all THREE albums (Let It Be, Past Masters Two, and this album).  Thus, it will all sound familiar.<br />Is this bad?  No, of course not.  There is some very good music here.  \\"Two of Us\\" and \\"Let It Be\\" are two of my favorites and they aren't all that different on this album.  The most jarring things on this album are (1) the inclusion of \\"Don't Let Me Down\\" (which, I think, belongs here as it and \\"Get Back\\" were probably two of the songs they focused on the most in the sessions) and (2) the omission of the studio chatter (which is striking because we've heard it for so many years).  The chatter was sort of dumb to include, but elements of it had become part of Let It Be.  \\"Two of Us\\" without the Lennon intro is weird at first.<br />So, is this indispensable?  No, absolutely not.  Is it a good listen?  Yes, and the version of \\"The Long and Winding Road,\\" while hardly anything truly new in view of McCartney's live albums, is worthy.<br />The second CD is a total throwaway.  Waste of time.  There is supposedly a full five-minute \\"Dig It\\" floating around somewhere in the session tapes.  That would have been more interesting than the flotsam and jetsam thrown in on the extra disc.  The real album is disc one.

B000002MU3|2.0|Coming into this album, REM were on a roll. They'd consolidated their fan base with the very good poppy &quot;Out of Time&quot;, then become possibly the biggest band in the world for a few minutes with the excellent &quot;Automatic For the People&quot;, a rare case where critical and commercial mass intersected. Then came Monster.<br />Given the continued artistic integrity of the band, one could interpret this as an intentional attempt to fight any expectations that may have been set up by Automatic. Surely, it would have been difficult to top Automatic. Surely, artistic integrity and the band's internal pride wouldn't let them simply make &quot;Automatic Jr.&quot; But instead we got this? A noisy rocking record who's greatest attribute is that it is...rocking? Too bad they didn't have enough other ideas, like interesting melodies, to accompany the rocking.<br />There's not a single track on this album that would rate in R.E.M's top 25 on a good day. The best of the bad lot are probably the two singles &quot;What's the Frequency Kenneth&quot; and &quot;Bang and Blame&quot;. Those are B-level tracks by the standards of lesser groups, but no better than C+ for a group like R.E.M.<br />The real shame of this album isn't that it's so lousy compared to anything else in the R.E.M. catalogue. No, the real shame is that this album managed to alienate a good portion of the audience that R.E.M. managed to win all their previous steller efforts. That means that way too few people heard really worthwhile subsequent efforts like &quot;New Adventures in Hi Fi&quot;, &quot;Up&quot; and (especially) &quot;Reveal&quot;.<br />And that's a shame.<br />Blame it on the Monster.

B0000DJZA5|4.0|By now, most everyone knows the story: Near the end of their career, The Beatles plan to record a set sessions wherein they 'get back' to the rootsier, less produced aspects of their music that have been long left behind. Unfortunately, the group is close to breaking up and the resulting acrimonious sessions, all captured on audio and video tape, are a mess. No one within the Beatles' camp has the energy or inclination to do anything with the resulting zillions of hours of tape, so they're turned over to outside producers, first Glyn Johns, then later Phil Spector. Both producers manage to cobble together a decent album from the tapes, but only Spector's gets released. (Johns' effort came close but got cancelled at the last minute).<br />The two versions of the album (Johns' and Spector's) differ in a few minor songs, but the biggest difference between the albums that Johns and Spector produced was that Spector added a swell of strings and other instruments to three songs: The Long and Winding Road, Across the Universe and I Me Mine. The changes to the former two are significant because these represent two of the better songs in the Beatles' estimable canon. The latter song is a rather minor Harrison contribution.<br />At any rate, since the album was first released there has been dissention in the former Beatles' ranks, most notably from Paul McCartney, about the album that came out. The complaints have mainly concerned the assertion that Spector's polished version doesn't represent the 'back to basics' aesthetic the Beatles were supposedly striving for in these sessions.<br />So what we have here, then, is supposedly an attempt to rectify that situation. This is supposed to be the 'raw' version of the Let It Be sessions, without Spector's sweetening. Does it work and is it really a revelation? Kind of, and not really.<br />In a nutshell, here's what the new release of Let It Be has done relative to the older version: 1) Considerable added production elements have been stripped from The Long and Winding Road, Across the Universe and I Me Mine; 2) Two short filler songs from the first release have been removed (Dig It and Maggie Mae) and replaced by the far superior track Don't Let Me Down; 3) The between-song patter has been removed. (&quot;Hope We Passed the Audition&quot;, &quot;here's hark the Herald Angels come&quot;); 4) The track order has been significantly altererd. There are modest changes to the other songs, but the meat of the changes is in (1)-(4) above.<br />OK, let's evaluate these changes one at a time:<br />1) The string-less Long and Winding Road is more intimate. But contrary to Paul's claims (and, heck, contrary to the version Paul did for his early '80s Give My Regards to Broad Street) the Spector strings do, arguably, enhance the track. It's a toss up. Across the Universe does sound better in the non-Spector version, although honestly it's not revalatory. And the non-Spector version of I Me Mine is inferior. Note that the no-string version of the Long and Winding road here is a different take than the one that appeared on Volume 3 of the Beatles Anthology.<br />2)The filler is not missed in terms of songs, but did actually serve a purpose in terms of reflecting the fragmented ramshackel nature of the sessions. It's nice to get Don't Let Me Down.<br />3) The between song patter is sorely missed. As with the filler songs, it added a greater sense of the true nature of the sessions.<br />4) The track reordering doesn't really mean much.<br />The bottom line is that the new album, while stripping away a lot of added production elements, also strips away a lot of the CHARACTER of the album by removing the silly ditties and between song patter. Although this is being marketed as the definitive reflection of the Beatles' original wishes, I would argue that, despite the Spector florishes, the original release is more reflective of what actually went on at the sessions.<br />There are some great songs on here, ineither version, and there's nothing inherently wrong with this new version. But it seems somehow ironic that this supposed definitive version is in some ways more cleaned up and LESS representative of the greater truth.<br />For my money, I think that while this is an interesting album, and surely worth having for completists or anyone hungry for ANYTHING new by the Beatles, the original release beats this one. I believe a better distillation of the sessions could be made that beats either album. But I don't know if we'll ever see that.her version, and there's nothing inherently wrong with this new version. But it seems somehow ironic that this supposed definitive version is in some ways more cleaned up and LESS representative of the greater truth. <br />For my money, I think that while this is an interesting album, and surely worth having for completists or anyone hungry for ANYTHING new by the Beatles, the original release beats this one. I believe a better distillation of the sessions could be made that beats either album. But I don't know if we'll ever see that.

0486282112|5.0|Modern readers must jump through a number of hoops to enjoy this legendary novel.  Written between 1816 and 1818, this is very much a novel of its era, and both language and ideas about plot are quite different from those of today.  That aside, and unlike such contemporaries as Jane Austen, author Mary Shelly has never been greatly admired for her literary style, which is often awkward.  But perhaps the biggest hurdle is that of our own expectations: while it certainly sent icy chills down the spines of 19th Century readers, FRANKENSTEIN is not a horror novel per se.<br /><br />While Mary Shelly might have been stylistically weak, her story was not.  Nothing like it had been written before, and the concept of a student endowing life upon a humanoid creature cobbled together from charnel house parts was unexpectedly shocking to the reading public.  But even more shocking were the ideas that Shelly brought to the story.  Having created this thing in his own image, what--if anything--does the creator owe it?  And in posing this question, Shelly very deliberately raises her novel to an even more complex level: this is not merely the conflict of man and his creation, but also a questioning of God and his responsibility toward his creation.<br /><br />In some respects, the book is written like the famous philosophical \\"dialogues\\" of the ancient world: a counterpoint of questions and arguments that do battle for the reader's acceptance.  More than anything else, FRANKENSTEIN is a novel of ethics and of ideas about ideas, with Mary Shelly's themes arrayed in multiple layers throughout: God, self, society, science; responsibility to self, to society, to the things we bring to society, to the truth; life, integrity, and death--these are the ideas and issues that predominate the book, and any one expecting a horror novel pure and simple is out of luck.<br />Mary Shelly is a rare example of a writer whose ideas clearly outstrip her literary skill--but whose ideas are so powerful that they transcend her literary limitations and continue to resonate today.  And indeed, as science continues to advance, it could not be otherwise so.  Mary Shelly could not see into the future of DNA research, laboratory-grown tissues, test-tube babies and the like--but between 1816 and 1818 she wrote a book about the ethical dilemmas that swirl around them.  And for all its flaws, FRANKENSTEIN is perhaps even more relevant today than it was over a hundred and fifty years ago.<br /><br />GFT, Amazon Reviewerl that they transcend her literary limitations and continue to resonate today.  And indeed, as science continues to advance, it could not be otherwise so.  Mary Shelly could not see into the future of DNA research, laboratory-grown tissues, test-tube babies and the like--but between 1816 and 1818 she wrote a book about the ethical dilemmas that swirl around them.  And for all its flaws, FRANKENSTEIN is perhaps even more relevant today than it was over a hundred and fifty years ago.<br /><br />GFT, Amazon Reviewer

B0000DJZA5|5.0|The Beatles - a common household name, a respected band, and pioneers of a sound. A sound which was perfected, for the final time, with &quot;Let it Be - Naked&quot;.<br />Spector is gone. Yoko is gone. All other outside influences who felt they could control the artistic ability of The Beatles and even do better are gone. All thats left is Sir Paul McCartney, Ringo Starr, and the souls of John Lennon and George Harrison for one last time. <br />&quot;The way it was meant to be heard&quot; is apparent in the first song.  I can't come here and review Beatles songs because they are timeless classics. These are not new material, these are old ideas applied to old songs. Nevertheless, a few key songs:<br />&quot;Get Back&quot;<BR>Whats changed? This is the &quot;shortened&quot; version, where ever Beatles fan is expecting the song to go on and getting nothing but track number 2. I think McCartney did well with this: while not a complete change in sound, its the change in the way the music was laid out, and its enough difference to note.<br />&quot;The Long and Winding Road&quot;<BR>My ONLY complaint on this album comes in the form of this song. I believe they removed the charm from it, adding in a lacking guitar (perhaps an organ too?) that doesnt make up for what it was before. Something sounds off about this.<br />&quot;Don't Let Me Down&quot;<BR>Perhaps my favorite of the re-released tracks is &quot;Don't Let Me Down&quot;. This IS the way it was meant to be heard, and this can be most apparently heard in the wonderful backing sounds of the organ that climaxes with a solo of sorts near the end of the song. The only word I could say is majestic, because thats what it is. McCartney and friends did right with this one.<br />&quot;Across the Universe&quot;<BR>Simply put, this is stripped of all the bells and whistles that machines of the day could produce, leaving us with John Lennons raw, enchanting voice. Its all we need now, and its all we should of gotten before.<br/>&quot;Let It Be&quot;<BR>The final song of the first CD, and rightfully so, this is the gem of this album. While nearly nothing has changed, it is the song itself that remains a classic and remains a testament to what was, and what passed. With a wonderful guitar solo to guide us through the middle of the melody, this song gives us the sense that we can finally &quot;Let It Be&quot;.<br />The second CD is a rare listen into Beatles studio life. Its an interesting listen, but nothing I could see myself listening to on a regular basis.<br />The Beatles, even after 33 years, still know how to do it right, and they did it right with &quot;Let it Be - Naked&quot;. Any Beatles fan, young or old, should appreciate this album. However sad it may be, an era has ended, but the soul of the music will live on forever.

Dan Brown references this symbol being used by the ancients before Judaism.<br />The subtle reference to the 325A.D. conference of priests and the casting out of certain Divine Teachings (like reincarnation) was thoughtful, historically accurate, and might help Catholic Christians better understand the levels of hell.<br />I very much enjoyed this.  What's next, Dan Brown?

At the end, instead of saying the word \\"breathe,\\" she just breathes...I thought this was a very cute touch. Very sensual song. <br />5. Early Mornin' <BR>You can definitely feel Moby in this song. The song talks about the night after partying and all...the way it is sung and was produced fits perfectly with the subject matter of the song. Britney also adds some spice to her voice that makes this song really nice to listen to. The talking part toward the end of the song...very good part that goes perfectly with the subject of the song as well. <br />6. Toxic <BR>My favorite track from the album! I just wanna be happy in a place where love is free! Can you take me there? Somebody? <br />8. Touch of My Hand <BR>I will be bold...going to the places I can be out of control! Music lovers of all genres will find something for them here. <br />I said this over and over in my review and I truly mean it -- Britney's vocals in In the Zone are INCREDIBLE and the songs (beats/tunes/etc) are GREAT. In the Zone is an absolutely fantastic album. <br />Go get In the Zone!<br />-Dan1113

B00005JKZV|4.0|Lord of the Rings is my all-time favorite novel!!<BR> And Peter Jackson's outstanding interpretation and adaptation does Tolkien's creation the most justice it has received since its original publication.<BR> This said, I have one very small, but justified complaint on Jackson's take.<BR> WHY, oh why, the Faramir-as-Boromir character cloning?? Faramir, as everyone who's read the book and loved his character, will tell you, was Frodo's best friend next to Sam in his trecherous journey through Middle Earth. To lose this comrade and help is to MAR the beauty of Tolkien's vision. We encounter too much repetition in a movie that is already full of it! (repetition of men being depraved and power-hungry slaves, repetition of Arwen's tossing away immortality, repetition of Frodo's struggle with the Ring...) While reminders do need to be dashed in here and there, as the movies are released one year apart, this was disappointing. The refreshing character of Faramir could have served as a reprieve from the chaos and uncertainty that poor Frodo and Sam faced, as it did in the novel. This violence and urgent movement from Faramir that PJ and cohorts think necessary absolutely was NOT necessary to keep the audience interested. I think it would have made more of an impression had Faramir been portrayed as the unique, truly-good, Aragorn-like character he was and not the brooding, rejected, less-favored, yet determined-to-be-well-thought-of son of Denethor into which Jackson made him. Tolkien's character is fully worthy of this speech: \\"I would not take this thing, if it lay by the highway. Not were Minas Tirith falling in ruin and I alone could save her, so using the weapon of the Dark Lord for her good and glory.\\"  This is a much different Faramir than in the movies, despite where he ends up when they part and his \\"quality\\" is finally shown. His \\"quality\\" was shown in that speech, would they have only left it in! <BR>I can understand and did enjoy pretty much everything else: theflowerly love story of Aragorn and Arwen, something I thought was beautifully shot and necessarily emphasized. The madness of Helm's Deep was perfect! The endless fighting and hopelessness they at times felt was right on. <BR>I liked the interpretation of Treebeard and the Ents. I enjoyed Eowyn and Eomer immensely and Theoden, despite his uncharacteristic stubborness. Though they did not empty the city, this gimmick works rather well. The urgency to keep Helm's Deep standing is not amplified. While mountain dwellers lived there, we did not have the time to be introduced to them, and their fate thus seemed unimportant. To have an entire city threatened was very clever indeed. Theoden's \\"exorcism\\" scene was an improvement upon the novel's subtlety and implied control of Saruman. His metamorphosis back to his original self, touching. Wormtongue was slithering, bastardly creepiness in the clever hands of Brad Dourif. <BR>And Gollum was perfection and everything I (and countless others) imagined him as, from as early on as \\"the Hobbit\\". <BR> All in all, it's still a fantastic movie! Just a little flawed. The Prince of Ithilien still balks at his mutilated role, however, as do his faithful following.

B00000J7JO|5.0|This album more than any other chili peppers album does not let down anywhere from start to finish. Besides that, it just has some truly incredible songs. I now have every one of their albums, but still this one is the best by far, even better than BSSM. That is because the guitar on this album is the most innovative thing john has ever done. For Californication, frusciante does not really seem influenced by any other guitarists. I mean, of course the influence is there, but the guitar work is the most original here of any other album. No other guitarist writes the simple beautiful melodic patterns that make up most songs on this album. This is where they reached a melodic peak, before it got a little too simple on By the Way. Oh, and although usually BSSM and Cali are considered the two best chili albums by fans, with BSSM being more popular, it is almost always agreed that the lyrics here are the best. Song by song:<br />Around the World: Best opening track you could ask for. Each instrument is introduced one at a time, and a simple funky verse leads perfectly into a melodic chorus. The lightest track on the album, closes with prolonged chord strumming, something found on several songs on this album.<br />Parallel Universe: This is a great rock song. Pretty different from anything else they have done because of the real fuzzy distortion on the chorus. Ends with another chord strum, this time with something of a solo over it.<br />Scar Tissue: Probably the most melodic song they have ever and will ever make, this is the prime example of johns melodic riffs. The musical interludes or solos are also perfect note choice solos.<br />Otherside: Likely the best song on the best album. The vocals here are haunting, the riff again is beautiful, and the lyrics are incredibly visual and symbolic but visceral. It also has an insane and hectic bridge (think 21st century schizoid man by king crimson) before going back to the chorus.<br />Get on Top: The funk on Californicationis so clearly different from any other upbeat sound they have. Its funky, but with a very melancholy tone, highlighted by the bridge of this song.<br />Californication: The title track is the second best song on the album. The riff here may be the best sound on the whole album, it just draws you in. The lyrics here are incredibly deep and sadly funny.<br />Easily: A song that sort of stands out on this album because its just rock all the way. Still, it has great lyrics and a nice solo with several guitars at the end.<br />Porcelain: One of the most hated songs by fans, but also loved by a smaller camp. I am one of the people who thinks this song is great. Really soft, a slow rhythm with a melodic guitar following the words.<br />Emit Remmus: An awesome song. The guitar here is just a couple of searing notes for the verse, as most of the sound is the drums here. All of the choruses on the album are great, and the one in this song is no exception.<br />I Like Dirt: This is a weird minor key funk that has a good solo, but the solo is very different from everything else on the album. It sounds a lot more like their older sound. In fact, that contrast works here perfectly, but still overall the song is weaker than the rest.<br />This Velvet Glove: Back to the great songs. This song has more terrific lyrics, another great riff that manages to still be completely original and different from the others, and a great chorus. No matter how the could play this song it would be sad.<br />Savior: Song pretty clearly written about john rejoining the band. The lyrics here are quite different, fewer symbols and images, more straightforward ones. This song has a stranger more experimental guitar sound, great outro solo.<br />Purple Stain: The lyrics here aren't as great as the rest of the album, but they are still smart and this song just rocks up until the closing strums.<br />Right on Time: A pretty light hearted song as far as this album goes. Still very good smart lyrics. One ofthe weaker songs on the album, but it flows well into the last song.<br />Road Trippin': An acoustic song that surprisingly works very well as a close. Great lyrics, and a nice simple organ part to keep it fresh.

B0000DYJM6|5.0|The first thing I want to mention is that the reason songs like &quot;Breath&quot; and &quot;State of Love and Trust&quot; (while great) aren't included in this collection is because they are readily available on a widely released cd, the &quot;Singles&quot; soundtrack, which is easy to find.  The rest of the songs on have either been released nowhere (Education, Hitchiker, Undone, etc...), are only found on Singles (Last Kiss, Alone, Other Side, Footsteps, etc...), or can only be found on difficult to locate compilation or benefit discs (Hard To Imagine, Whale Song, Gremmie Out of Control, etc...).  <br />Next, it's obvious why some of these songs did not make albums, but it's not because they are weak in any way.  Many of the songs just don't fit into the overall mood of the particular album sessions they were recorded during.  They are no less great because of this, it's just that the band members and some others couldn't find a way to get them on the albums.<br />A personal highlight for me is the commentary the band members have on the songs, especially when you see that some of the songs were personal favorites of band members for the particular album (such as Ed's favorite songs &quot;Down&quot; and &quot;Alone&quot; from those respective recording sessions, and Mike's affection for &quot;Yellow Ledbetter&quot;, which he still doesn't know what the song is about).  It is very disappointing the one of my favorite pj b-sides &quot;Angel&quot; was cut out of the cd at the last minute, but that's a minor argument.  The other songs here more than make up for that unfortunate matter that was beyond the band's control.<br />Another song worth mentioning is the haunting &quot;4/20/02&quot; written the day Layne Staley died.  It's a solo performance by Ed, and there's obvious anger there, and disappointment.  It's a great tribute, and it was nice (relatively speaking) to hear how Layne affected his friends.<br />All in all, pearl jam has proven why they are one of themost respected and well known rock bands in recent history.  With b-sides of this quality, how can you ignore the sheer talent of these five (well, 8 including all the drummers) individuals.  Great album.

Sure, I liked the beginning of &quot;Still Life&quot;, but after the first 2:44 it went downhill...or so I thought at the time.  In truth, I just didn't listen to it enough to really appreciate the amazing guitar work.  However, I can honestly say that I am not a big fan of Bruce Dickinson's vocals...it's not that they don't sound well with the music, it's just that I don't like that high pitched type voice (you see, I'm used to listening to James Hetfield of Metallica).  Nevertheless, I didn't feel that not liking the vocals affected my enjoyment of this CD too much.  There were several songs where I DID enjoy the lyrics as well as the guitar work.<br />     I'd have to say that my favorite song on this CD is &quot;To Tame A Land&quot;.  It really demonstrates the right way to have a song over seven minutes that is interesting the entire time.  The guitar work in that song is so varied that you often times forget you're still on the same song.  I made that mistake the first few times I was listening to the song...I started falling asleep and then woke and thought that the CD started over again, but then I realized my CD player doesn't do that, and I was like, &quot;What the...?&quot;, and then it dawned on me that I was still listening to the same song.  It really is that varied. <BR> <BR>     Another of my favorites was &quot;Flight of the Icarus&quot;.  This was one of the few songs on this CD where I thought the vocals were absolutely astounding.  I love midway through the song, when the lyrics start, &quot;Just a babe in a black abyss/No reason for a place like this&quot;.  That may be the best part of any song on the entire CD.<br />     There were, however, a few songs I didn't care for.  Number one on that list was &quot;Quest for Fire&quot;.  How can you take any song seriously that starts off with &quot;In a time when dinosaurs walked the Earth&quot;?  I like songs that actually mean something to me, or can express in song what I feel emotionally.  I don't think there is an emotion that would correspond with that. <BR> <BR>     The other song I didn't care for was &quot;Sun and Steel&quot;.  There really wasn't any one reason that I would pinpoint for not liking that song, it just didn't appeal to me.  Maybe it's because, again, I couldn't really relate with things like &quot;You killed your first man at 13&quot;, etc.  It might also have been because I don't like hearing two or three voices singing at once, to me that sounds like I'm at my sisters middle school chorus concert, espcially when they are as high pitched as those in this band.  <br />     Overall though, I really liked this CD.  It was definitely worth my money, and it also gave me something new to listen to now that I've heard every Metallica album.  The friend that recommended this to me said he thought it was their best album.  I can't be the judge of that since this is the only one that I've heard, but I can honestly say that this is one of the best albums I have heard in a long time, and I'm definitely going to be purchasing more Iron Maiden in the near future!
B00005JMFO|5.0|There is very little really not to like about this charming collage of a movie. <br />Brilliant ensemble of actors, and thus by implication great cameos from the ilk of Hugh Grant, Liam Neeson and Emma Thomson; credible romantic vignettes intercut together, and thankfully not too saccharine to be implausible (not everyone ends up in their preferred romance for instance); a fair bit of nudity (a big bold \\"R Actually\\"); and above all, some delectable humor -- there are sentimentalistic crests but swiftly followed by a jibe or crack that balances the narrative. <br />The vignettes: <br />-- Colin Firth as a writer with a soft spot for his Portuguese maid while working on a novel in a French town<BR>-- Liam Neeson as a widower managing his grief by lending his teenager son a hand with his love life <BR>-- Emma Thomson as the cheery wife of Alan Rickman, an executive who is falling prey to the come-ons of an office colleague<BR>-- Bill Nighy as a spent-out rock star on the comeback trail with a holiday version of the Trogg's \\"Love Is All Around\\"<BR>-- Hugh Grant as a wonderfully self-deprecating bachelor prime minister in love with a benign British version of Monica Lewinsky <BR>-- Laura Linney as an American expat with a romantic life that suffers due to her obligation for her autistic brother<BR>-- Andrew Lincoln as a tortured bloke madly but secretly in love with the trophy wife (Keira Knightley) of his best friend<BR>-- Kris Marshall as a would-be superstud trying to get to America (he's \\"cocksure\\" his British accent will be a chick magnet)<BR>-- Martin Freeman and Joanna Page as two innocents who fall in love while working as stand-ins in a porn movie <BR>-- Billy Bob Thornton as a nasty U.S. president who gets his comeuppance <BR>-- Rowan Atkinson as a prissy department store clerk<br />What more can you ask for in one sitting? B000092ZYX|5.0|I write this here only because I feel I have to. The 1 star ratings the album is getting by reviewers with two or three unexplained, vague sentences is aggravating and simply not fair. I just read a longer, more intelligent review that gave it 2 -- the Floyd fan -- and that I can take, but the mindless reviews that are bogging down the overall rating of the album is ridiculous.<br />I don't know what to say, this is a good, GOOD -- no, great -- album. Admittedly, Radiohead is probably my favorite band. That's not to say I've always understood, or even liked them. The Bends is a rocking album filled with emotion and angst, be it whiny or not, and the number of memorable ballads on it is unmatched by most. I'm only 20 -- and quite a screwed up 20 year old as is -- but it was an album that at a point in my life really hit a note with me, lyrically. Anyway, OK Computer obviously came along and took over the world, and for good reason. It's probably my favorite album of the 90's; the music is downright brilliant, they create a technological ambience without losing emotion or Spirit (something I can't seem to say of Floyd, who's Existential themes and other-worldly soundscapes are no doubt intellectually captivating but leave me feeling empty, and really just tired, inside), combining awesomely symbolic lyrics with boatloads of energy and passion. Let Down and No Surprises are sublime masterpieces that few bands will ever touch. (I just keep going don't I?) So yeah, Kid A came, it was even more of an experiment... And I loved it. Radiohead taught me the definition of progressive rock, and Kid A exemplifies that. It's edgy, subversive, a journey, really. It's an album that you haven't heard if you haven't listened to on a pair of nice headphones. I'll be the first to admit the effect is far different than than that of OK Comp (it probably leans more towards the Floyd-esque sound/melody), but it's totally captivating nonetheless. Amnesiac, well... An album I was first disapointed by due to it's completely bizzare nature (far more so than Kid A) eventually turned out to be enchanting and utterly hypnotic. Admittedly it's a bit of a skewed album, and the song structure is questionable, but I found lying down, eyes closed, headphones blaring, to be almost Religious. I'll spare you any more gushing.<br />Anyway, now that I've finished up that uneccessary summary, we have Hail to the Thief. On a purely intuitive level, this is my 2nd favorite Radiohead album, shortly behind OK Computer. It's unquestionably more entertaining than either Kid A or Amnesiac -- if not quite as epic -- and is, to be utterly blunt, a f@#*ing blast. There's a profound, visceral energy to almost every song on the album. Does it &quot;ROCK&quot; like OK Computer? In my opinion, it's a, &quot;GOD YES DOES IT EVER!&quot;. &quot;2+2=5&quot;, &quot;Where I End and You Begin&quot;, &quot;Myxomatosis&quot;... These songs rock. Admittedly, the whole album doesn't rock in such a sense, but even other songs like &quot;The Gloaming&quot;, &quot;There There&quot;, and &quot;A Punchup at a Wedding&quot; have a very complex, yet melodic structure that I deem as rock-worthy, even if they don't immediately stand out as such. I think the combination of Kid-A/Amnesiac-esque synthesizers -- not quite as complex or innovative, but still brililant -- and forceful rythms and melodies makes this album stand out on it's own, easily.<br />I've read comments about how this album doesn't flow, and that's strange, because I myself would say the Tao itself was bursting through (almost) every moment of the recording stage here. &quot;We Suck Young Blood&quot; (which I like, yet is my least favorite) disturbs the flow more than anything else on the album, but otherwise it's like butter. <br />Bottom line, this album is technically superior to 99% of the stuff out today, even if it might be a small step backwards as far as sheer creativity is concerned. Quite frankly, I'm ALL FOR them taking a step back, because this is the most entertaining album I've heard in at least a year. To get a good idea of my tastes, my two other favorite albums of the year are probably The Coral's &quot;The Coral&quot;, Dave Matthews &quot;Some Devil&quot;, and Interpol's &quot;Turn On The Bright Lights&quot;, though that one may be 2002. <br />Anyway, get it.

B0000DJZA5|4.0|First the good news: the songs have been beautifully remixed.  The superior sound quality was evident from the opening riff of Get Back as soon as it hit my speakers.  Let's face it, if you've been listening to these songs for the past thirty odd years (as I have), then you know every nuance.  Kudos to the remix team, and one can only wish they'd give Abbey Road a shiny new coat of paint.<br />But now the bad news, as you've already heard.  This is not your father's Let It Be.  The ghost of Phil Spector has been thoroughly exorcised.  On the songs that he applied the Wall of Sound, I suppose that's a good thing.  For example, Across the Universe has always been one of my least favorite Beatle songs, the version on Anthology went along way towards resurrecting it from the doldrums, and this new mix is an improvement over either the Spector mix or the single version available on Past Masters 2.<br />But perhaps my biggest complaint is that none of the songs supposedly recorded on the roof that January day sound live.  Every song on this disc, while pleasant and crisp, sound as though they came from the Apple Studio.  I always thought that the chatter that filled out the original album gave a nice feel for the loose atmosphere of their final concert.  To be fair, though, I have a complete bootleg of the Rooftop Concert, where they played Get Back three times.  The version on the Let It Be album I have always suspected was the studio version with chatter added for effect.  For proof, I present to you the third version of Get Back as presented on Anthology 3.  This was where John hoped they passed the audition.  John and George's amps were cut off by the police in mid-song, and one can see George turning his back on in the film.  This guitar-less mix is not on either of these Let It Be albums.<br />And yes, I am an obsessive Beatle fan.<br />Further, this new album claims to be as the Beatles recorded it in January 1969.  As many well know, I Me Mine wasn't recorded until January 1970, after a brief rehearsal snipped was included in the film.  This was at the Beatles' final recording session, when John was on holiday.<br />All of this may be splitting hairs, but one can't help but feel that the only reason that this version is seeing the light of day is because John and George aren't here to veto it.  Rest in peace, lads.

B0000DJZA5|4.0|Let It Be has long been an anomaly in the Beatles catalog, and one of great debate. McCartney has gone down on record more than once stating that he has despised Phil Spector's production and window dressing treatments, and so with the release of Let It Be...Naked, an attempt to irradicate Spector's &quot;criminal&quot; mistreatment is made with crisp, crystal clear remastering and no fluffy string arrangements or between song banter to be found. But is it any better?<br />My answer is yes and no. <br />First the positive: The remastering is astounding. Instrumentation previously unheard now rises to the surface. Vocals are clearly heard, and an excellent job was done to capture an overall live feel as if you're in the room with the Beatles. &quot;Get Back&quot; and &quot;I Me Mine&quot; sound like definite improvements arrangement-wise and sonically to the previous well-known versions, IMO.<br />Now the negative: unless you're McCartney, someone close to the Beatles camp who was involved in the recording process, or a serious Beatle fanatic who probably already owns stripped down versions of these songs in bootleg form, then you're a probably a typical listener like myself who only knew the Spector recordings and now finds the stripped down versions, well... stripped down and incomplete. Whether you like the Spector recordings or not, they are the classic recordings that the general public has known and loved (or hated, depending on who you are). They're such a part of our musical history and vocabulary that Spector's treatments, for better or for worse, are every bit a part of the overall sonic makeup of the songs, whether McCartney can except that or not. So hearing &quot;The Long and Winding Road&quot; now without the fluffy arrangements sounds a bit unfinished and missing something, even if those string arrangements were possibly the most offensive additions Spector contributed to the album. And &quot;Let It Be&quot; has lost a bit of it's punch, opting for thetamer guitar solo to the grittier solo found on the original recording. (Q: is this the same version found on the Beatles blue album 1967-70?). Considering what Spector had to work with: hours and hours of recordings of partially unfinished songs, loose jams, dialog, etc., I think he did an admirable job in trying to tie it all together into some sort of cohesive, uniform concept. Sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn't, but I promise you if you grew up knowing his versions by heart you will now find yourself missing some of his treatments. <br />The other negative aspect of the recordings, and I'm prepared to get flamed by Beatle fans here, are not with this specific re-release but with the Beatles performances themselves. Let It Be was and will always be somewhat of an abandoned child; a mish-mosh, hodge podge of great moments, okay moments, and toss offs, and will still stand as one of the Beatles weaker overall album efforts no matter what you do to it, especially when sandwiched between superior more consistent releases like the White Album and Abbey Road. That's not without stating that it has obvious high points as well, as few would deny that the title track or &quot;Across the Universe&quot; are some of the finest Lennon/McCartney songs ever written, and even the weaker moments are of a higher caliber than most bands, but for the Beatles the overall album feels a bit sub-par. (One wonders what these songs might have sounded like had George Martin smoothed away some of the rough edges). But it's easy now, in retrospect, to fabricate some &quot;concept&quot; tag on the album as their &quot;raw, live, bare bones release&quot; (granted this is true, and in fact, that is what distinguishes it from all other Beatles albums), when I tend to think that this kind of conceptualizing was tacked on by those who were afraid to admit that the Beatles might not be infallible after all and only AFTER it was already apparent that it was not on the level of their past releases. <br />As it were, Let It Be...Naked serves better as a curiosity rather than a necessary edition to your Beatles catalog, and sufficiently answers the question of what might had been had the Beatles had their way with the recordings. But if you're still missing LIB in your collection my suggestion is get the original Spector versions, simply because those are the classic recordings, like it or not.

It wonderful how the song &quot;Wasted&quot; can make you get down! The last song on the album makes you think of anime cartoon opening credits. &quot;Try Me&quot; i think is the weakest song because of its length.

B0000CDLA7|5.0|I was skeptical about this album after reading a few negative reviews posted here.  With my first listen of TOT, my fears were blown away. I do realize every one of us has different tastes /opinions. Some of fans obviously didn't expect the album to be that heavy yet complex to ears so they do complain. Someone calls it an evolution; others might think its crap. But guess what, the band could not and will never please everyone. Every step that Dream Theater takes (just like any other band) can be assessed in a different way, and I personally happen to dig new material.  After a few listens now I keep asking myself if this is their best. Maybe. And again, it is different from the rest of DT albums just like any of them is different from one another.<BR>Yes, my jaw was dropped after I heard angry sounding lyrics with some rapping and excessive language, heavy guitar and keyboards tone and some similarities to modern metal music. But, all that went with incredible playing of every member of the band, unexpected vocal harmonies, beautiful melodies and excellent musicianship. And the best part is that the album grows on you with each listen: you tend to find new elements in songs that you think you are now familiar with every listen.  Yes, this is easily their heaviest to date, no question, and they do incorporate some of that'nu-metal' into their songs.  But, who cares if they do it with class so that even those moments should not sound that bad to a melodic metal listener at all.<BR>There are seven songs on the album and only one of them is a 3-minute, piano driven ballad. All others are about or over 10 minutes long (one of them being an instrumental). The opener 'As I Am' is a straightforward rocker that gives a hint on what direction Dream Theater's taking with TOT. Petrucci goes totally insane and shreds like there's no tomorrow.  He does that on other songs as well showing he's no stranger to keep speed, melody and precision all in one. If I were to choose the best songs on the album, I would probably go with 'Endless Sacrifice' and 'In The Name Of God', but that might change after more listens as every song grabs me and sends me shivers or makes me smile.<BR>So, do not fully trust complainers and check the album out for yourself. I cannot assure you will fall in love with it. I do guarantee though that you will hardly find any other amazing, top quality album like this in today's world.

B000002UTY|3.0|Quicksilver Messenger Service were the greatest guitar band of all time.  When it comes to improvisational jamming, NOBODY could rival them.  John Cipollina, my favorite guitarist in the world, and Gary Duncan together were an unbelievable force.  Unfortunately, though, this album doesn't feature them at their best.<BR>The 25-minute \\"Who Do You Love\\" suite starts out excellently, with John and Gary jamming away like there's no tomorrow.  But only certain parts of it are truly great.  John's solo (\\"How You Love\\") is full of fire, but it still doesn't show what he was REALLY capable of (for that, check out the compilation album LOST GOLD AND SILVER, in which his playing is beyond all words and comprehension).  Gary's solo (\\"When You Love\\") is more or less the same way.  And the closing part of the suite is totally awesome, with the band slowly and quietly building up the tension until...BOOM!, they tear into it again and resume jamming, as John repeatedly nails those high notes to the point where you think he's never gonna stop.<BR>\\"Mona\\" is pretty much boring, with no real excitement added to it.  \\"Calvary\\", on the other hand, is a total trip.  This is unquestionably the best song on the album.  It was recorded in the studio with overdubs, not in concert, but it really doesn't matter because the song is so great.  It features some of the most frightening, spaced-out notes that ever came from an electric guitar.  And when I say 'frightening', I don't just mean 'eerie', I mean downright SCARY.  Some parts of it are truly breath-taking, and all of those weird moans in the background are so creepy that they sound like ghosts in a graveyard.  I'm not kidding.  Don't listen to it in the dark.<BR>\\"Maiden Of The Cancer Moon\\" is just John fooling around again and not showing us his true potential.  And the title track is a fun little country western tune, kind of a strange way to end an album, but this is Quicksilver we're talking about, so I think we can forgive them.<br />So happy trails to you, until we meet again!
0446677450|1.0|First of all, let me say that this book is certainly well written. I have no doubt that Kiyosaki is making a lot of money from these books. But, I ask you, take a real close look at these reviews. Is anybody posting success stories? And saying how? By naming names?<br />A great deal of this book is in the new style of motivational writing. Every page you read is selling this book. And while I certainly don't doubt that it can inspire a great many people, when you put this book down you find that you haven't learned anything new that hasn't been said before.<br />I was shocked to see that some of the things that Kiyosaki recommends are horribly outdated. For example, he goes into great detail how he bought foreclosed property for little money down, and then turned it around to make a profit. Hey, this was a great moneymaking idea - back in the 1970s! But now, even he admits that if you try to do this you're going to find that there are hundreds of people, with the same idea, trying to buy the same property! So, why did he just explain a moneymaking scheme where the odds are overwhelming against you?<br />Another method he mentions is how he made money buying stock before it's offered for sale to the public. Kiyosaki forgets to tell you that this is called an Initial Public Offering (IPO), and it's damned difficult to get one - unless you either have connections or are extremely lucky.<br />Out of the 204 pages of this book, the actual practical advice can be summed up on maybe two pages. Here's the best advice from this book:<br />1. Buy ASSETS instead of LIABILITIES. This is the secret to making money without working. But Kiyosaki forgets to mention the famous axiom that goes along with buying assets: &quot;You need to have money, to make money&quot;<br />2. Buying a house is often a lousy investment. Banks make you believe that you're getting a terrific tax deduction by paying interest. The only problem is that for every $100 you get back in taxes, about $350 is wasted money, totally flushed down the toilet.<br />3. Understand Sales and Marketing, and be good at it.<br />4. Understand tax law.<br />I see a lot of well written reviews on this book. Professionally written reviews. I suspect that these reviewers have all learned from Kiyosaki's sense of style.<br />&quot;Most people work for their money. Rich people have their money work for them&quot; Gee, you know how much work it takes to write a 204-page book? And, at my count, he's written about 15 books.<br />You know, just because a book calls itself different, doesn't mean it is. If Kiyosaki's rich Dad really does exist, I suspect that he made his money writing books.

B00009TB5G|5.0|First off, for those so-called \\"purists\\", I remember specifically in the Special Edition of FOTR that Peter Jackson stated that he and his entire crew wanted to make a movie \\"based\\" on Tolkien's masterpiece that would be suitable for those that have read the books and for those that have not yet done so and still stay true to the overall story. He has done that in my honest opinion.<br />Therefore, in the scenes where Merry and Pippin meet up with the White Wizard, and when Aragorn falls off the cliff, the movie leaves the viewers who have not read the books in a state of suspense. It keeps their attention and adds some adventure to the movie. For those of us that have read the books, we know what the outcome will be. To me, there is nothing wrong with this at all. The overall story has NOT been changed.<br />Peter Jackson's goal was to create a movie that would hopefully bring in even more fans to read the books and to introduce them to what JRR Tolkien had worked so hard to create: a world with it's own history, languages and people that pulls the reader in and makes them forget about the real world for a few hours. Peter Jackson has done that with his rendition of The Lord Of The Rings trilogy. It stays faithful to the overall story, which is the quest for the one ring, and it's destruction. Unfortunately, the purists are selfish in their feelings, but they are in the minority here.<br />In this extended version of the Two Towers, new scenes have been added while others have been extended. Over 200 new visual effects were added and Howard Shore once again has redone the musical score as they did for the extended version of FOTR.<br />The appendices are excellent. The appendices in the FORT and the Two Towers are examples of how DVD's should be put together. Hours upon hours of behind the scenes documentaries exist that are not slapped together, but put into a logical order. As with the FOTR, you have the option to play all of them together with one press on your remote or to watch them separately at your leisure.<br />The Map of Middle Earth is back to show the continuation of the journeys of the broken Fellowship, which to me is a wonderful tool. Those questions have been answered with this DVD.<br />Also, there is a hidden Easter egg on the first DVD of the movie with Gollum and the MTV awards that is hilarious. Not as funny as the SNL skit on FOTR, but still hilarious. So far, I must say he has done a commendable job. I felt that the theatrical version of the Two Towers telling of the various stories seemed almost too short and slapped together. I think it's because so much of the story had to be left out that fleshed out the details, especially with Treebeard and the Ents. However, more of that story has now been added to this special extended version and this, like the FOTR extended version, is surely going to please the rest of us even more than the original theatrical version.<br />This movie rates 5 stars in my book.
